allNoteData.Name: Chapter 1
Notes:
Python variables do not need explicit declaration to reserve memory space. 

The declaration happens automatically when you assign a value to a variable. The equal sign (=) is used to assign values to variables.

Python allows you to assign a single value to several variables simultaneously. 

For example −  a = b = c = 1
Python has five standard data types −  Numbers String List Tuple Dictionary

allNoteData.Name: Chapter 2
Notes: In programming, data type is an important concept.  Variables can store data of different types, and different types can do different things.  Python has the following data types built-in by default, in these categories:  Text Type:	str Numeric Types:	int, float, complex Sequence Types:	list, tuple, range Mapping Type:	dict Set Types:	set, frozenset Boolean Type:	bool Binary Types:	bytes, bytearray, memoryview

allNoteData.Name: Chapter 3
Notes: There are three numeric types in Python:  int float complex
Example x = 1    # int y = 2.8  # float z = 1j   # complex

allNoteData.Name: Chapter 4
Notes: Strings in python are surrounded by either single quotation marks, or double quotation marks.  'hello' is the same as "hello".  You can display a string literal with the print() function:
Assigning a string to a variable is done with the variable name followed by an equal sign and the string:  Example a = "Hello" print(a)
